[SYNTAX]: Long and complex sentences that disrupt the flow
[ANACHRONISM]: "e-ink wallpaper" is a modern technology in a historical novel
[STYLE]: Inconsistent use of archaic language with modern elements

[LOGIC]: Sudden transitions between scenes could be smoother
Some character motivations could be more clearly explained

[SYNTAX]: "Debby had suffered so much... that the subject had ceased to interest her" has awkward syntax
"I have even tried to trace her family for I believe..." has awkward transition
"She gathered herself up and turned a set, white face to her mistress" is awkwardly phrased
[LEXICON]: "thou art seen with Jack Martin" uses archaic language inconsistently
"’tis not like I’d forget Jack" uses archaic language
[GRAMMAR]: "Debby had had a hasty answer ready for Mrs. Lane" has awkward double past tense

[TIME]: Inconsistent time period with modern elements like "LED ceiling" and "delivery robot" in historical setting
[LOGIC]: Sudden shift to modern technology disrupts narrative flow
[CHARACTER]: Abrupt transition from Debby's defiant conversation to her contemplative state
[TRANSITION]: Jarring transition from Debby's thoughts about her father to modern technology
[CONTEX]: Modern elements seem disconnected from overall narrative and historical context
[PLOT]: Introduction of modern technology in historical setting creates confusion
